DataElement.preferredName: Magnetic Resonance Imaging Computed Tomography Diagnostic Imaging Abdominal Cavity Pelvis Physical Examination Ind-2
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the yes/no indicator whether magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), a procedure in which a magnet linked to a computer is used to create detailed pictures of areas inside the body, or computed tomographic (CT) scan, a method of examining body organs by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis, was used to assess or evaluate the pelvis, the structure of the vertebrate skeleton supporting the lower limbs in humans and the hind limbs , or abdomen, the area of the body that contains the pancreas, stomach, intestine, liver, gallbladder, and other organs.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Magnetic Resonance Imaging Computed Tomography Diagnostic Imaging Abdominal Cavity Pelvis Physical Examination
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), a procedure in which a magnet linked to a computer is used to create detailed pictures of areas inside the body, or computed tomographic (CT) scan, a method of examining body organs by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis, being used to assess or evaluate the pelvis, the structure of the vertebrate skeleton supporting the lower limbs in humans and the hind limbs , or abdomen, the area of the body that contains the pancreas, stomach, intestine, liver, gallbladder, and other organs.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Magnetic Resonance Imaging Computed Tomography Diagnostic Imaging
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Non-invasive method of demonstrating internal anatomy based on the principle that atomic nuclei in a strong magnetic field absorb pulses of radiofrequency energy and emit them as radiowaves which can be reconstructed into computerized images. The concept includes proton spin tomographic techniques.:Tomography using x-ray transmission and a computer algorithm to reconstruct the image.:Any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues for diagnostic evaluation..

Concepts.definition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.
A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.
Any method that uses a visual display of structural or functional patterns of organs or tissues for diagnostic evaluation.

Property.preferredDefinition: That portion of the body that lies between the thorax and the pelvis.:The structure of the vertebrate skeleton supporting the lower limbs in humans and the hind limbs or corresponding parts in other vertebrates.:A physical examination is a systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion, and auscultation, aimed to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for individual's health assessment.

Concepts.definition: The cavity located between the lungs and pelvis. It contains the lower esophagus, stomach, pancreas, intestines, liver, gallbladder and spleen.
The bony, basin-shaped structure formed by the hipbones and the base of the backbone supporting the lower limbs in humans.

A systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion and auscultation. The purpose is to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for an individual's health assessment.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The preferred Value Domain to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The affirmative response to a question.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual domain that includes value meanings to be used for Indicator Value Meanings such as Yes, No, Unknown, No Applicable

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A caDSR representation term that is used to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no

Concepts.definition: A response or indicator that can have a value of either yes or no.

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text1
ReferenceDocuments.description: Was a CT or MRI of the abdomen performed?

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF_Text_2
ReferenceDocuments.description: MRI of the abdomen and pelvis AND [a chest x-ray (PA and lateral), or CT/combined PET/CT scan of the chest]

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text 3
ReferenceDocuments.description: Abdomen: CT scan with IV contrast (preferred); or MRI (acceptable)
